ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about what I needed to write a good essay and what to actually be looking for when I read other essays, and it was a great introduction in being in a seminar as well.

I learned a variety different writing skills including crafting a proper lede that grabs attention, how to establish focus, authority, significance, and tension effectively, using free indirect discourse, oblique judgements, false impressions, and artful juxtaposition (among many more). I learned how to balance the use of personal self in creative writing.
First and foremost, writing technique. Beyond that, the class also helped develop a system in which to think critically about what one is writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There is a ton of feedback on your writing, and even though the grading is rough, I could feel my writing improve throughout the semester. Sometimes, I think there were too many readings, and we didn't get time to go over all of them in class, or just review them on our own.
The course was very effective and well structured.

The strengths would be the numerous articles we read. Seeing good writing and breaking it down greatly helped improve my writing. Another strength is simply the act of writing itself. The way the course is structured necessitates that we write multiple essays spread across various types of writing. This breadth and subsequent feedback helped me develop an increased fluency in different types of writing. In line with feedback, the feedback mechanism for the course was also instrumental to the strength of the course. Through "workshops," we were able to peer edit work, and those being edited were able to ask and have their questions answered. The diversity of opinion again contributed to the quality of writing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely, even if the grading is difficult, I think I really improved my writing and taught me what to look out for whenever reading someone else's or my own essays.
YES! English 120 will make you a strong writer even beyond creative writing.

I would recommend the course. Seeing good writing and breaking it down greatly helped improve my writing. The way the course is structured necessitates that we write multiple essays spread across various types of writing. This breadth and subsequent feedback helped me develop an increased fluency in different types of writing. In line with feedback, the feedback mechanism for the course was also instrumental to the strength of the course. Through "workshops," we were able to peer edit work, and those being edited were able to ask and have their questions answered. The diversity of opinion again contributed to the quality of writing.

Absolutely! Every moment was interesting; we discussed a delightful breadth of essays in class. Also, Professor McGowan's feedback is just unmatched in its detail and pointedness. It really helped my essays improve.
